awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Improving the Accuracy of Juror Self-Reports of Bias during Rehabilitative Voir Dire
awd_abstract_narration:
The courts have long acknowledged pretrial publicity as a source of juror bias. To safeguard defendants' rights to a fair and impartial jury, the courts frequently attempt to "rehabilitate" jurors who admit bias by asking them if they could set aside their bias and be fair and impartial. Yet research indicates that jurors' self-reports of their ability to be fair and impartial are largely inaccurate. For example, regardless of their level of exposure to pretrial publicity, jurors typically report an ability to be fair and impartial. Therefore, this practice of juror rehabilitation is ineffective. Enhancing self-reporting accuracy is critical given that inaccurate self-reports not only undermine defendants' right to a fair and impartial jury but can also create additional litigation, thus requiring valuable time and resources from the courts and weakening public confidence in the accuracy and legitimacy of the legal system. The present research  examines how conformity pressures from the judge and other jurors influence jurors' self-reporting accuracy and tests the effectiveness of a novel intervention designed to increase the accuracy of self-reported bias. 

This project examines the mechanism behind jurors' inaccurate reports of their ability to be fair and impartial and the effectiveness of juror rehabilitation in two jury simulation experiments. First, this project will test whether the behaviors of the judge, other jurors, or both are influencing jurors' self-reporting accuracy by fostering pressures for them to conform their behavior to the request of the judge and other potential jurors. Second, this research will test the effectiveness of an intervention for decreasing conformity pressures during juror rehabilitation and attenuating the biasing effects of pretrial publicity on jurors' decision making. Research shows that pretrial publicity biases jurors' decision-making in part by creating source monitoring errors wherein jurors confuse evidence learned from pretrial publicity with evidence presented during trial. The proposed intervention allows jurors to reflect on and write down information obtained through pretrial publicity prior to being questioned about their ability to set aside bias and be impartial. This intervention should decrease conformity pressures and source monitoring errors and, in turn, increase self-reporting accuracy. In addition, the proposed research will involve students enrolled at a Hispanic-serving institution as research assistants, contributing to the preparation of students from underrepresented groups for graduate study in the sciences.

por.por_cntn:
This research focused on the accuracy of jurors’ statements of impartiality during voir dire (jury selection) in the context of exposure to pretrial publicity. Pretrial publicity often prejudices jurors against defendants, making them more conviction prone than jurors who only hear the trial evidence and thus undermine defendants' rights to a fair trial. Traditionally, the courts have handled jurors who express bias during jury selection, such as bias resulting from exposure to pretrial publicity, by asking them if they can set aside their bias and be impartial—a process known as “juror rehabilitation.” However, almost all jurors who have been exposed to prejudicial publicity say they can be impartial after this rehabilitation process, suggesting jurors’ statements of impartiality are inaccurate. We sought to understand what the source of the pressure to report impartiality was and whether the accuracy of jurors’ responses could be improved. Specifically, we tested the efficacy of an exercise asking jurors to reflect on their knowledge about the case and how it might impact their decision-making prior to being asked the rehabilitation question.

We recruited nearly 500 community members from 35 states to participate in a mock jury selection and trial simulation in person or online through Zoom videoconferencing. In the first part of the study, half of participants were exposed to prejudicial news articles about a real murder trial and the other half read about an unrelated case about embezzlement of child support funds. In the second part of the study, participants were questioned about their knowledge of the case by a judge and then asked if they could be impartial in front of confederate-jurors. Next, they watched a videotaped trial, which we had recreated from actual footage and filmed, and completed a series of questionnaires.

As expected, most of our participants said they could be impartial regardless of their exposure to pretrial publicity or their participation in the intervention designed to increase their ability to assess their bias. Those jurors exposed to pretrial publicity still demonstrated a bias towards conviction, demonstrating that their self-reports of their ability to set aside their biases and be impartial were inaccurate. Of particular concern was the finding that jurors exposed to pretrial publicity were just as confident and motivated in their ability to be impartial as their non-exposed counterparts. Our attempts to increase the accuracy of jurors’ self-reports were unsuccessful, possibly because conformity pressures exerted by the judge and fellow jurors may be so powerful that changing the norms of the situation is virtually impossible or because jurors genuinely - but erroneously - believe they can be unbiased.

Our finding that jurors are unable to accurately self-report bias suggests the oft used process of juror rehabilitation is, contrary to the courts’ presumption, not successfully combatting juror bias. Concerningly, inaccurate self-reporting can waste more of the court’s invaluable time and resources by creating additional litigation, preclude defendants’ constitutional right to due process, and undermine the prosecution’s ability to prove guilt. We suggest that rather than continuing to rely on the practice of rehabilitating jurors or resorting to alternative solutions, which have also proven ineffective, the courts consider novel alternatives grounded in social psychology, such as using other-directed questioning or having neutral third parties probe jurors on potential bias.
